In the past, indeed until very recently, no one
considered that radio or television could do very
much more than provide "course enrichment,"
"supplementary" materials. As a result, very little
of what exists, is applicable to the problems in
education today. New techniques for the in-school
use of radio and television, the now familiar
"courses for credit by television," the "Continen¬
tal Classroom," have become historic landmarks in
the application of electronic communications media.
It is for this reason, because serious innovation
has occurred on a high level, that there is reason
to look forward to lasting results on the frontiers
of education today.
Secondly, because we will have to create new ma¬
terials, we must decide what we want those materials
to do, and is it important that we measure results
by accepted standards. We know that when learning
occurs it is measurable, but does that only apply
to learning when It occurs in those settings which
we have come to regard as "academically acceptable?"
